captions.text: [Intro Music]

Oh boy I&#39;ve been looking forward to Bomb Rush 
Cyber Funk. And yes, that was the last time I&#39;m

going to call it by its actual name. We like to 
have fun taking the piss out of titles here on

Zero Punctuation and this is enough meat to see 
me through the winter, right here, can&#39;t even say

it without sounding like a confused grandparent 
reading aloud the highlighted words on the side
of their grandchild&#39;s can of energy drink.

Talk about a verbal car
crash, I don&#39;t even know where to put the dry heave.

Or even if I&#39;d be dry heaving because of
unnecessary colons or just dry heaving unrelatedly.

Well, anyway, pace
yourself, Yahtz, start with a mild one.

Bum Rush Cyber Flunk is a new game very
deliberately setting out to evoke the Dreamcast&#39;s classic

graffiti skating game Jet Set Radio, also
known as Jet Grind Radio, apparently in accordance with

the rule that this kind of thing has to be
titled the way an oblivious mother dresses their child

in a three-piece tartan suit for their first
day of school. This isn&#39;t one of those blood-stained

or mighty number nine-altered by the same
author stealth remake situations, the original devs

aren&#39;t involved as far as I know, but the
desire to be a pseudo-stealth sequel to Jet Something

Radio hangs off of bum flush kyber junk like
an infected piercing. It&#39;s got a similar visual style,

i.e. like the Saturday morning cartoon
version of You Got Served, and it&#39;s gone out of its way to

look convincingly like a game on the
Dreamcast, i.e. like a Playmobil set based on the above that

got sneezed on by a
coal miner, all janky animation

and blurry textures.
And of course the gameplay is

based around skating through a futuristic
city doing graffiti and outfoxing a ludicrously

overfunded police department, all set to
music that sounds like a very excitable person got their

synthesizer caught in a car door. The story
is, you play a graffiti artist skater boy who gets

busted out of prison by another graffiti
artist skater boy but gets decapitated by an insane DJ

on the way out, so the second skater boy
instead of like calling a doctor or asking if you&#39;re okay

or anything like that jams a robot head on
your body and announces you&#39;re going to help him and

his crew take over the city, his crew
consisting of you, him, and some perpetually jiggling girl

who hangs around very
conspicuously not explaining
her presence. From this I got the impression that

the plot of poo-tush pilerspunk doesn&#39;t
actually matter that much, which is a shame because it

started mattering later on and I kinda wished
I&#39;d paid more attention. Meanwhile, your actual task
is to go to each district of the city, paint over

all the occupying gangs
graffiti, and then challenge

them to a stylish skating contest. Thankfully
this isn&#39;t one of those serious skating games where

there&#39;s a dedicated control for everything
from pushing off to diving face first into a concrete

step. Again, it&#39;s the Saturday Morning
cartoon version, you snap onto grind rails like they&#39;re

made of streaky bacon and your board is
an unsupervised labrador, and then press buttons

to do tricks. &quot;Oh but don&#39;t just randomly
mash the trick buttons,&quot; warns one of your NPC friends,

and then the actual gameplay waits for her
to leave and says &quot;Yeah, just randomly mash the

trick buttons, it&#39;s fine.&quot; Still, I was
missing something, cause when I challenged the South Side
crap-outs or whatever the very first

easiest-to-beat gang in the
game were called, they proceeded to

stomp me in stylishness points no matter how
many ollies I cracked off in a row. I dropped the game

for a few days after that, but something made
me go back. Maybe it was every other game I played

that week not quite scratching the right
square inch of bollock, or maybe it was the innate charm

of bong hits, cider drunks, retro
graphics, tragically 90s vibe, and endless parade of

gyrating bottoms. I returned to the
battlefield and remembered that games about rewarding

stylishness very
rarely actually do. I mean, if an

AI can&#39;t even point
out all the squares containing

traffic lights, why would you think it
knows anything about style? No, the thing to do in

this sort of game is figure out the one thing
the game gives inordinately high points to and then

do that over and over again. In the case of
bum gush diarrhea bucket, your secret weapon is the

corner. Yes, those innocuous seeming points
where two grind rails meet from different angles aren&#39;t

just jolly useful for pedestrian safety,
they&#39;re the secret path to victory. Every time you lean

into a corner while rail grinding, you add
one to your score multiplier and that shit mounts up.

You do have to lean into it, though.
Circumnavigate an entire food court while standing upright,

boo amateur hour, sod off back to the swing
set, tommy pickles, do exactly the same thing while

leaning slightly to the right, yay
superstar, consider yourself served, rest of universe.

Your other secret weapon is the manual
button, so your combo immediately ends if you touch the

ground, even if you&#39;re so much as prodded
with a toe, in between using your skateboard to perform

high level particle physics experiments.
But, if you hold down the right trigger as you land,

you do a manual, and that does not break
your combo. Then you can manual your way over flat

ground until you find another grind rail
with another seven or eight corners, or as I prefer

to call them, angel clitorises. So again, do
9000 tricks and touch the ground, that&#39;s scrub shit,

go get a job in the toilet so you can scrub
shit some more. Do 9000 tricks and touch the ground

with your feet at a slight angle, all hail the
new emperor of the cosmos. And once I knew all that,

bog brush cyber twat was almost trivially
easy. Although I was having fun. Sometimes it&#39;s nice to

play a game that doesn&#39;t feel the need to
point a nail gun at my gonads and command me to dance,

and I could zone out and lose
myself for hours just skating around the city,

idly wondering if the game&#39;s
interface will bugger up if I get my combo over 999.

I do have black marks on my
examination sheet, the combat is a complete wash,

it&#39;s like slapping balloons on a conveyor
belt, so the police are more of an irritant than a
challenge. The five enemy gangs you go up against

are a bit
underdeveloped as characters, and during

the battle sequences I might as well have
been pitting my skills against a Dance Dance Revolution

machine hanging from a meat hook. And the
music ranges from decent to someone&#39;s beating me to

death with a malfunctioning drum machine,
and I kept hearing the same songs over and over again

so either there aren&#39;t enough tracks or that
was when the concussion set in. But that&#39;s all baby

new potatoes compared to the button that
squash that is the fact that plop splutched spider

hemorrhoid is a fun game. I&#39;ve always had a
soft spot for pure traversal gameplay and this hits

a good balance between skill and breezy
fun. I admire how you don&#39;t unlock abilities, they&#39;re

all available from the start and you just have
to figure them out. And after I had I could restart

the game and when the jiggly lady in the
tutorial went &quot;see if you can get a combo of ten&quot; I could
go &quot;you mean like this?&quot; and then still be

comboing into the hundreds
hours later long after her face

had been fully melted off. This isn&#39;t
nostalgia, I&#39;ve never played Jet Set Radio and never owned

a Dreamcast because, well, one hardly needs
to justify that statement. I&#39;ve also never put my
[Outro Music]
